newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS - Australia minister sees solid economic growth.
newsitem.headline: RTRS - Australia minister sees solid economic growth.

text.p: Australian Assistant Treasurer Rod Kemp said on Monday the government expected strong economic growth to continue in 1996/97.

"We expect solid growth to continue this year and are forecasting real GDP (gross domestic product) growth of around 3.5 percent," Kemp told a Metal Trades Industry Association of Australia conference.
The forecast is line with the government's 1996/97 budget prediction.
Kemp also said Australia's current account deficit remained a problem.
"It is wrong to conclude that the current account problem is over," he said.
Kemp said the main challenges facing the government were to boost national savings and reduce the current account deficit, which stood at A$1.330 billion, seasonally adjusted, in August.
"It has been argued by some that the recent decline in the current account deficit - which has been significant - means that it is under control," he said.
"While this statement is true, it is wrong to conclude that the current account deficit problem is over."
He said improvement in the current account deficit during the past year was the result of cyclical, rather than structural factors and the fact that it had come off a high level.
Kemp said national savings were too low to keep the current account deficit at a comfortable level.
"Higher national savings, which helps address the current account deficit and takes pressure off interest rates, can be expected to boost growth and employment over the medium term," he said.
Kemp also said the government expected to meet its 8.25 percent unemployment rate target for 1996/97.
"The government is also expecting a fall in the unemployment rate, although this will be muted to some extent as people are encouraged to enter or re-enter the workforce," he said.
"Hence, the unemployment rate is forecast to fall only modestly to around 8.25 percent by next June."
Employment growth was expected to strengthen through 1996/7 as a result of continued strong economic activity and expected moderation in real wage growth, he said.
